TopicTitle: What are the space center buildings made of?

Articles.Content:
I have a question about what the space center buildings are made of.

mostly for animation purposes, but it'd also be good to know.

I personally think plastic... but i want to hear your opinions.

Unobtanium.

That's what their made of.
I assume they're made out of the same things that buildings are made of here. Concrete, glass, metal girders...
Old Nintendos.

I assume they're made out of the same things that buildings are made of here. Concrete, glass, metal girders...

Yeah, but they don't look like they're made of concrete... but i'll render something out and see what they looks like.

Old Nintendos.

Are you sure they aren't made of Nokia phones?

Well seeing as you can crash a rocket the size of a battleship on them and they don't even get damaged, I'd say they're made out of Nintendium. (That being the material that Nintendo handhelds are made from. Seriously, screens aside, those things are practically impossible to damage unless you really try!)

Old Nintendos.

Nintendium is probably a great guess...

No matter how many craft you smash into them, as long as you blow on 'em a bit, they'll just keep working...
It need to be pretty tough to withstand all the impacts, maybe tungsten?

Nintendium is probably a great guess...

No matter how many craft you smash into them, as long as you blow on 'em a bit, they'll just keep working...

Well seeing as you can crash a rocket the size of a battleship on them and they don't even get damaged, I'd say they're made out of Nintendium. (That being the material that Nintendo handhelds are made from. Seriously, screens aside, those things are practically impossible to damage unless you really try!)
It need to be pretty tough to withstand all the impacts, maybe tungsten?

Okay, since i didn't mention this, i may as well say it.

It's not about the strength, i mean by how it looks.
Nokium. 10char

Okay, since i didn't mention this, i may as well say it.

It's not about the strength, i mean by how it looks.

Metal can take on any kind of pattern and just about any look.
A highly refined alloy of plot armor, unobtanium, adamantium, and with a special kind of shielding that prevents any outside forces other than gravity and the planet's crust from affecting them.

It need to be pretty tough to withstand all the impacts, maybe tungsten?

While tungsten is very hard and has an insane melting point, it's actually quite brittle. You can take a 1/8" tungsten welding electrode and snap it in half with your bare hand. Yes, hand as in singular. A steel wire the same size would just bend.

Titanium would be a better choice for a building material, much stronger and lighter.
If they construct their buildings out of the same things they apparently use to construct their rocket parts: EXPLOSIVES!
castironium

Videogamium, an indestructible element that forms almost everything in a video game. Fun Fact: Videogamium is transparent on the inside, and if the camera is placed inside a solid videogamium object, the outer shell is completely see-through.

Videogamium, an indestructible element that forms almost everything in a video game. Fun Fact: Videogamium is transparent on the inside, and if the camera is placed inside a solid videogamium object, the outer shell is completely see-through.

Is that also what trees are made of in the GTA games?

1001010101010010010111010101010101010...etc.

But it tastes like chicken.

Metal can take on any kind of pattern and just about any look.

Indeed.
Solid Neutronium. That's why they don't ever get damaged.
Concrete reinforced with Nokianium.

Painted/Colored Alamantium...while the rockets sometimes feel like old plastic

Edited November 15, 2013 by Duke-49th

An extract from the story I wrote about the rebuilding of the space centre:

The buildings at KSC are made with an insanely strong material called Nokianite.

It's also terribly heavy, becomes brittle with long exposure to radiation, and requires constant electric protection to prevent corrosion.

So some sort of plastic/metal matrix..

Edited November 15, 2013 by Tw1

Reinforced polygonite (pronounced pol-IG-o-nite ) is what most video game buildings seem to be made of. It takes a very specific process to break them, where no amount of brute force will do the job. And yet somehow Nokia managed to bring this nebulous code-stuff into the real world.
